results.title: Worse than Xmas
results.creator_credit: Julie Harris, Mandy Walker and Joanne Aslanis
results.brief_description: Waitress Angela (Kaarin Fairfax) rushes home to save a doomed relationship. When she fails, she agrees with her neighbour that Easter is the worst time of year, even worse than Christmas. The film follows the funny and inevitable diversions that Angela takes to make it through the breakup and start dating again.

results.title: What the Water Gave Me

video_links.name: Florence + The Machine - What The Water Gave Me

constellations_other.name: From gallery to screen
constellations_other.description: Explore how famous films, videogames and music videos have taken their cue from the art of the past.

results.description: The music video for ‘What the Water Gave Me’ intersperses footage of Florence + the Machine’s studio recording sessions with kaleidoscope shots of Welch performing the song, evoking the crashing of waves and reflective quality of water.
description_for_label: The music video for ‘What the Water Gave Me’ intersperses footage of Florence + the Machine’s studio recording sessions with kaleidoscope shots of Welch performing the song, evoking the crashing of waves and reflective quality of water.

results.title: Zoomfilm
results.brief_description: An experimental film dedicated to the “blink”. Dynamic abstractions (created through use of prodigious optical printing and directly working the film frame) investigate the nature of human optics. Music by Maurizio Kagel.

results.title: Zoo with class
results.creator_credit: James Mann and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of all aspects of the Melbourne Zoo Education Service. Looks at its philosophy on environmental education, the teaching programmes, curriculum developments and cosultancy. The program also reveals how the zoo education service can become an extension of the classroom and seeks to enable teachers to plan school-based environmental education programs in which the zoo school plays an integral role.

results.title: Zoo Dance
results.creator_credit: Tony Paice and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Dance movement programme operates at the Royal Melbourne Zoo. Its aims include encouraging creativity and communication between students and teachers, self-expression, building self confidence. Available to children with disabilities as well as the regular school student.

results.title: Zoo creatures great and small
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Rob McCubbin and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Andrew Tribe, zoo veterinarian, and Jeanne de Lacy, zoo keeper, both from Royal Melbourne Zoological Gardens, Zoo Education Service Staff, are interviewed by Trevor Lunn. Animals come to the zoo, often after car accidents and are examined and treated in the veterinary department or nursery. Training for zoo keepers and zoo veterinarians is discussed.

results.title: Zoo babies: observing things about us
results.brief_description: Designed to teach young children to observe more carefully the things about them. This film compares the habits and physical characteristics of various baby animals at the zoo. Animals studied include monkeys, gnus, lions, peacocks, alligators and bears.
results.description: Designed to teach young children to observe more carefully the things about them. This film compares the habits and physical characteristics of various baby animals at the zoo. Animals studied include monkeys, gnus, lions, peacocks, alligators and bears.

results.title: Zoo animals of our story books
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Background for Social Studies”.
Designed to stimulate young children’s interest in reading stories about animals that can be seen in a zoo. These animals are compared with the character found in storybooks, such as tigers in “Little Black Sambo”, deer in “Bambi” and bears in “Goldilocks and the Three Bears”. The film concludes with an invitation to the children to make up their own story based on the character “Bubble the Elephant”.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: ostriches
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Bill Walker and Coronet Films
results.brief_description: The ostrich is the tallest and heaviest of all bird species, using its feet and sharp talons to protect itself against other animals. Shows the courting behaviour of the male and female ostrich as well as the care of the young. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
